description: New Latin proventriculus (19th century), from pro- +â€Ž ventriculus.

entries.meaning: (zoology) The part of the avian stomach, between the crop and the gizzard, that secretes digestive enzymes. [from 19th c.]
examples: In fulmars, the proventriculus is very baggy, and has thick wrinkled walls lined with glands that excrete the waxy oil which courting birds pass to one another in small amounts, perhaps as a way of scent-marking their mate.

entries.meaning: (zoology) A similar part of the digestive system in insects and myriapods. [from 19th c.]
